comment: Spend first 7 orbits continuing on north (because we will break continuity with the ecliptic, later). Ecliptic longitudes in this schedule are a tad different from reality, which will point antisun at perigee of every "mid-sector". MAIN SCHEDULING CONSTRAINT: We will switch to ecliptic at "optimal time", which according to the efficiency vs observing time plot LGB made is orbits 68-77 inclusive, or Sep 30 2020 through Feb 14, 2021. (Someone at SPOC will check -- LGB will ensure this). We will spend 10 orbits on the ecliptic. The rest of the schedule -- south afterwards for 26 orbits, north for the remaining orbits, follows from the fixed dates required by the ecliptic survey.

Begin observing the ecliptic (comment above explains time). Do it continuously, for the 10 orbits that it is possible. Goal: maximize sky area covered. To achieve the goal, in first sector shift backwards by ~10 degrees in longitude. In last sector, shift forwards by same ~10 degrees. Spread out evenly in longitude between those. This leads to advances of 20.777 degrees forward per orbit.
Advance in ecliptic longitude. Perhaps shift slightly in latitude to fill in gaps. (Could apply principle to all pointings, could ignore this in planet yield simulations).
Last ecliptic field. Typically 211 sc_boresight_elon would be antisun.
Go south. (Would begin "extended mission sector 9"). [Note: there's a little slop in the anti-sun ecliptic longitude here, but this schedule is adequate for planet yield simulation purposes].
end FY2022 is Sep 30, 2022. orbit 121 is last orbit of ExtMission1.
